text: So the Symbolic Cognitive Robotics Project asks the question, what does it take at a minimum for a simple mobile robot to survive in a world it knows initially very little about?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So the focus is on learning through engagement with an agent's environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It focuses on the development of agency
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: in a robot, which starts with very little in terms of cognitive constructs and through engagement, through acquisition of experience, grows a society of mind, a collective of simple cognition actors
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: which each one quite specialized in terms of what it can perceive and what it can do.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And they all work together in the sense that a Caucasian actor will, through observations of its umwelt, generate synthesized beliefs, which will then become
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: observations to more abstract cognition actors.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you have this ladder of belief abstraction that is built up through active engagement in the environment through
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: learning what simple perceptions mean, learning what affordances there are, what can the robot do.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And as the robot grows its collective of cognition actors, the conjecture is that it will detect trends and
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: how its beliefs, its more and more abstract beliefs, map homeostatic signals.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Am I doing something that benefits my survival and my continued survival?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So it's really a project about how an agent learns its own agency.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: learns its affordances, learns to make sense of its perceptions through more and more elaborate beliefs.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And all of this sense-making is grounded in the survival imperative.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Now, of course, the physical robot is not mortal.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: I mean, I can turn it off, turn it back on.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's still there.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's like your computer.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But the society of mind will grow through its experiences, through its learning, is itself mortal.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And I set up an experimental environment such that the robot has a minimum amount of time in order to grow competencies at exploring and foraging.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Otherwise, it expends its store of energy without ever replenishing it.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So it needs to forge to replenish.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It needs also to avoid collisions because collisions are deleterious to its health.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It needs also to keep a level of engagement, otherwise it
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It essentially retreats away from the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So all these motivations activate this society of mind that the robot grows over time.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And all I'm trying to do is set up these mechanisms and launch the robot and see if it can grow, make up its own mind basically about the world it needs to engage with.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So there are notions of collective intelligence, there are notions of mortal computing, there are notions of grounded sense-making, affordance discovery.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: There's also a very big nod
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: to Immanuel Kant and his epistemology, because the robot needs to develop causal theories of its perceptions.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: How can I predict what I will perceive next?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: is is very important so a very strong notion of predictive processing based on the discovery of causal theory how do i make sense uh of of the perceptions and the actions that i that i engage into how can it how can i predict what happens next
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And all these concepts are brought together in a hole that hopefully leads to autonomous agency and really simple Lego robots, which brings in a dimension of fun as well, because these robots are really fun to build and fun to run.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And my hope is that not only does the robot get to learn how to survive, but that we can observe its behaviors and its visible states and subject them to an active inference analysis and be able to demonstrate that, yes, indeed,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The robot reduces its variational free energy and gets better at it over time or not.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So it's a very fun project.
